Deep learning prior models from seismic images for full-waveform inversion
Conference Paper · September 2017

SEE PROFILE

Deep learning prior models from seismic images for full-waveform inversion
Winston Lewis∗, Schlumberger and Denes Vigh, WesternGeco
SUMMARY
Downloaded 08/17/17 to 73.32.60.128. Redistribution subject to SEG license or copyright; see Terms of Use at http://library.seg.org/

Full-waveform inversion (FWI) is now a mature technology
that is routinely used in exploration around the world to ob-
tain high resolution earth models. In geological areas such
as the Gulf of Mexico, however, reconstructing complex salt
geobodies poses a huge challenge to FWI due to the absence
of low frequencies in the data needed to resolve such features.
A skilled seismic interpreter has to interpret these geobodies
and manually insert them into the earth model and repeat this
process several times in the earth model building workﬂow.
Deep learning algorithms have gained a lot of interest in re-
cent years by obtaining state-of-the art results in various prob-
lems arising in the ﬁelds of computer vision, automatic speech
recognition and natural language processing. We investigate
the use of these algorithms to generate useful prior models for
full-waveform inversion by learning features relevant to earth
model building from a seismic image. We test this method-
ology in full-waveform inversion by generating a probability
map of salt bodies in the migrated image along with a prior
model and incorporating it in the FWI objective function. This
approach is shown to be promising in enabling an automated
salt body reconstruction using FWI.
INTRODUCTION

Full-waveform inversion is a promising technology that the
seismic industry has to produce high resolution earth models
that fully explain the recorded seismic data. Although the the-
ory for FWI was developed in the 1980s (Tarantola, 1984), it
is only in the last decade that major advances in high perfor-
mance computing power provided by the graphical computing
units (GPUs) enabled a widespread adoption of FWI on ﬁeld
datasets (Virieux and Operto, 2009; Vigh et al., 2011; Kapoor
et al., 2014). However, geological areas such as the Gulf of
Mexico (GOM) pose a huge challenge to FWI due to the pres-
ence of high contrast complex salt geobodies. Given the long
wavelength nature of these anomalies, running FWI with an
initial model without a reasonably accurate representation of
these geobodies already present in the model would lead to cy-
cle skipping and cause the inversion to converge to a wrong
solution. Several approaches to overcome this challenge have
been investigated (Esser et al., 2015, 2016). Here we investi-
gate a data driven approach that mimics what interpreters nat-
urally do in the current model building workﬂow as it might
have better success with ﬁeld datasets.

Deep learning (LeCun et al., 2015) is a branch of machine
learning that has generated widespread interest in recent years
by breaking previous records for recognition and classiﬁcation
tasks in image and speech processing. The algorithms that
come under deep learning are essentially variants of artiﬁcial
neural networks but with a signiﬁcantly deeper layers of neu-
rons than what have been used in the past. Although invented

in the 1980s and 1990s, neural networks didn’t ﬁnd widespread
adoption due to being very expensive to train even for simple
models. The advent of GPUs and the massive amount of data
available during the last decade transformed this ﬁeld just as it
did with FWI. The availability of highly efﬁcient and parallel
solvers on GPUs have enabled training of deep networks in a
short period of time. The deep learning approach to solving
classiﬁcation and segmentation problems in medical imaging
has shown signiﬁcant success (Greenspan et al., 2016; Setio
et al., 2016) in discriminating between normal and pathologi-
cal biological tissues.

Seismic interpreters have long relied on a number of different
attributes computed from a seismic image to guide them in the
interpretation process (Halpert et al., 2008; Wang et al., 2015).
Here we investigate an approach to apply deep learning meth-
ods to seismic images and attributes derived from it to generate
a probability of a region of the seismic image belonging to a
salt geobody. We do this by using the prior that salt geobod-
ies found in Gulf of mexico regions usually don’t have well
deﬁned structure and hence discriminating between structure
and lack of structure in seismic images is a reasonable indi-
cator of the presence of salt. This a priori information is then
used as an extra regularization term in the FWI objective func-
tion which guides the inversion towards the prior model.
THEORY

The classical formulation of the full-waveform inversion prob-
lem is posed as the minimization of the objective function,

min
m f(m) = 1

where F : M →D is a wave equation modeling operator that
given a earth property model m ∈M (velocity, density, etc),
simulates synthetic seismic data, d ∈D the seismic data mea-
sured in the ﬁeld and ∥· ∥2
2 represents the squared L2 norm.
An adjoint-state method (Plessix, 2006) is used to compute the
gradient g(m) = ∇f(m) and iterative optimization algorithms
are used to minimize the objective function.
Prior model regularization

Seismic inverse problems are generally ill-posed and their so-
lution is non-unique and unstable. Regularization in the form
of incorporating additional information about the nature of the
solution is essential to obtain a reasonable solution to the in-
verse problem (Tikhonov and Arsenin, 1977; Zhdanov, 1993).

In model space, this is achieved by introducing a priori infor-
mation in the inversion procedure about the earth’s subsurface
structure in the form of a functional J(m). We have the regu-
larized objective function as,

min

where mprior is some a priori model, usually set to zero when
nothing is assumed to be known, and, Γ is the Tikhonov matrix
that can be interpreted as the conﬁdence we place on the prior
model. This approach has been successful on ﬁeld datasets
in constraining the model updates around the well by creating
prior and conﬁdence models using the well log information
(Vigh et al., 2015) and also ensuring model updates are geo-
logical and consistent with the structure in the seismic image
(Lewis et al., 2014). In a similar fashion we would like to
build a prior model that represents our best guess of the loca-
tion of salt geobodies in the current model and use it to guide
the current model towards a solution which also incorporates
the predicted salt geobodies.
Convolutional Neural Networks

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are a kind of deep learn-
ing model that are specially well suited to process images.
They are a specialization of the neural network (LeCun, 1989)
designed to process input data that is speciﬁed on a grid, such
as an image. They differ from a regular neural network in that
they replace the matrix multiplication operation of a regular
neuron by a convolution. By making the explicit assumption
that the inputs are images, they are able to greatly reduce the
number of unknown weights that need to be trained in each
layer. This allows one to build deeper models thus allowing
them to learn highly complex non-linear relationships from the
inputs.

The typical architecture of a CNN is shown in Figure 1. They
are made up of interconnected layers, commonly made up of
only three layer types, convolutional layer (CONV), pooling
layer (POOL) and fully-connected layer (FC). The CONV lay-
ers parameters consist of a set of ﬁlters whose ﬁlter weights are
determined in the learning stage. Every ﬁlter is small spatially
(along width and height), but extends through the full depth
of the input volume. Periodically a pooling layer (POOL) is
inserted in-between successive CONV layers. Its function is
to progressively reduce the spatial size of the representation to

reduce the amount of parameters and computation in the net-
work, and hence to also control overﬁtting. Neurons in a fully
connected layer (FC) have full connections to all the activa-
tions in the previous layer, as done in regular neural networks.
A softmax layer is used as the ﬁnal layer of the network. It
converts the output of the ﬁnal fully connected layer, which
outputs arbitrary values, into a probability distribution for the
output classes.

Many CNN architectures have been proposed and shown to
obtain breakthrough classiﬁcation accuracy on image classi-
ﬁcation challenges.
The most well known of these are the
LeNet (Lecun et al., 1998), AlexNet (Krizhevsky et al., 2012),
GoogleNet (Szegedy et al., 2014) and VGGNet (Simonyan and
Zisserman, 2014) CNN architectures. Here, instead of invent-
ing our own CNN architecture, we investigate the performance
of the AlexNet architecture. Only minor changes are made to
adapt it to our needs since the original network is geared to-
wards predicting a large number of classes of natural images.

Figure 2: Deep learning workﬂow.
Deep learning prior models

Our deep learning workﬂow for generating prior models is
shown in Figure 2. We ﬁrst prepare a training and validation
dataset using earth models that are representative of the geol-
ogy in Gulf of Mexico. We generate migrated seismic images
from the known velocity models and the ground truth annota-
tion indicating the locations of regions of each image contain-
ing the salt geobodies. Together these are then used to extract
image patches from the seismic images and label them as those
containing structural features and those without as can be seen
in the top left of Figure 2. Before these image patches can be
used for training, careful pre-processing is needed and steps
such as normalization and rescaling are applied.

These image patches are then input into a deep learning model
along with the associated labels. The training is computation-
ally demanding and depending on the number of input images,
the kind of model used and the solver parameters, can take
anywhere from a few hours to days even on the latest GPU
hardware.

When running FWI on an unknown dataset we ﬁrst use the
starting velocity model to obtain a migrated seismic image.
This image forms our test dataset. We apply the same pre-
processing steps used in creating the image patches for our
training dataset and extract overlapping image patches at de-
sired output locations in the image. We then use our previously
trained model to output a probability of each image patch con-
taining structural features. We can then use this probability
map to create a conﬁdence model of the salt geobodies.

Now, using the above computed probability and the knowledge
that the salt velocity is about 4500 m/s, we can create a prior
Run prediction

model that contains salt velocity in regions of high salt prob-
ability and velocity from the current model everywhere else
where this probability is low.

We can now use this generated prior model in our regularized
FWI objective function (2) with an appropriate regularization
weight to guide the inversion towards incorporating features
from the prior model into the inversion result. This prior model
generation is repeated every time we have a velocity model that
is sufﬁciently different from the velocity model we last used to
obtain the migrated seismic image. This newly migrated im-
age is used to create a new prior model which can constrain
the subsequent iterations of the inversion. Algorithm 1 speci-
ﬁes the complete description of this deep learned prior model
regularized FWI workﬂow.
RESULTS

We test our method on the subsalt multiples attenuation and re-
duction technology (SMAART JV) Pluto 1.5 model. The Fig-
ure 3 (a) shows the starting model used for FWI. The starting
model is created by removing the salt geobodies from the true
model and applying a heavy smoothing to the sediment only
velocity model. To generate the training and validation dataset
for the deep learning model, we use the Sigsbee2B (Paffenholz
et al., 2005) model and some inline sections of the SEAM 3D
salt model (Fehler and Larner, 2008). In total about 90,000
image patches were extracted from these datasets along with
the ground truth labels. It is important to mention that no in-
formation about the Pluto dataset itself was used in either the
training or validation datasets. The training is performed on a
8x Tesla K80 GPU node and took about 39 hours for 200,000
Deep learning prior models for FWI

Figure 3: (a) Starting velocity used for inversion and prior gen-
eration (b) Predicted salt geobody conﬁdence overlaid on the
seismic image.
iterations.

Before starting the FWI iterations, a migration is performed
using the Pluto starting velocity to obtain a seismic image which
is then used as the test dataset for our trained deep model. This
model generates a conﬁdence model of the salt geobodies as
shown in Figure 3 (b) overlaid on the seismic image. Using
this conﬁdence map along with the prior information that salt
velocity is 4500 m/s we use the current velocity model to re-
place the high probability regions with salt velocity to generate
our prior model.

Now we perform some inversions with the starting Pluto veloc-
ity where we limit the usable data frequency in the 3Hz-8Hz
bandwidth. We ﬁrst use the regular FWI workﬂow (ie data
misﬁt only objective function in Equation (1)) without a prior
model. The inverted velocity model after 25 iterations can be
seen in Figure 4 (a). The inversion gets stuck into a local min-
imum and only the top layer of the salt geobody has been re-
covered. This is because the majority of the data sensitivity is
to the top salt-sediment interface alone, which gets recovered
reasonably in the inversion.

We now run the prior regularized FWI workﬂow. The inver-
sion result after 25 iterations can be seen in Figure 4 (b). Even
though we are still far away from the true model, we have re-
covered the bulk of the salt geobody information and seem to
be headed in the right direction. This shows that our use of the
prior model is nudging the inversion to incorporate these geo-
bodies in the inversion result by adding the long wavelength
features missing in the data gradient alone.

Figure 4: (a) FWI inverted model without any regularization.
(b) Regularized FWI inverted model with the deep learned
prior.
CONCLUSIONS

We have demonstrated a data driven workﬂow to build prior
models for FWI by learning features from the seismic image
using state of the art deep learning models. We apply this to the
problem of salt body reconstruction by learning the probability
of salt geobodies being present at any location in a seismic im-
age and using this information to regularize the FWI objective
function. Doing this we show that long wavelength features of
the model such as salt can be introduced in the model which
due to lack of low frequencies in the data is really challenging
for FWI to achieve using the seismic data alone.

Future work will aim at validating our approach on ﬁeld data,
and comparing its performance to the interpretations obtained
by expert seismic interpreters, with the ultimate goal of gradu-
ally bringing automated salt body reconstruction using FWI
into the earth model building workﬂow. Although here we
have focused our efforts toward the problem of salt body re-
construction, what we have presented is a general regulariza-
tion strategy that can be used to incorporate any prior informa-
tion that can be learned from a seismic image into FWI.
